context: SAP held 24% ERP market share in 2010, maintaining market leadership. Cloud computing transformation beginning with SaaS models gaining acceptance. SAP acquired Sybase for mobile and database capabilities. Oracle-SAP duopoly in large enterprise segment. In-memory computing emerging with SAP HANA announcement.

competitors.name: Oracle
competitors.notes: Second-place ERP vendor with Oracle E-Business Suite and Fusion Applications, combined with database dominance creating integrated competitive offering

competitors.name: Microsoft Dynamics
competitors.notes: Strong competitor in mid-market with Dynamics AX, NAV, GP, and SL products, leveraging Microsoft ecosystem and Office integration

competitors.name: Infor
competitors.notes: Third-largest ERP vendor with extensive portfolio from acquisitions, offering industry-specific solutions competing with SAP verticals

competitors.name: NetSuite
competitors.notes: Leading cloud ERP platform for SMB and mid-market, demonstrating viability of SaaS model before Oracle acquisition in 2016

competitors.name: Workday
competitors.notes: Rapidly growing cloud-native HCM and financial management competitor, disrupting SAP's HR and finance modules with modern UX

competitors.name: Sage
competitors.notes: Leading SMB ERP and accounting software provider with products like Sage 100, 300, 500, and X3 competing below SAP Business One

competitors.name: Epicor
competitors.notes: Mid-market ERP vendor strong in manufacturing, distribution, and retail verticals with industry-tailored solutions

competitors.name: IFS
competitors.notes: Component-based ERP competitor specializing in project-based industries, service management, aerospace, defense, and asset-intensive sectors

competitors.name: Salesforce.com
competitors.notes: Cloud CRM leader expanding into broader enterprise applications, competing with SAP CRM and threatening platform expansion
